It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family, which includes many species with unique floral structures. The plant produces small, clustered yellow flowers surrounded by modified leaves called bracts. It typically grows in moist, sandy soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Acalypha brittonii is often found in wetlands and along stream banks, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local wildlife.
